awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multiscale Investigation of Thixotropy in Soft Clays
awd_abstract_narration:
Thixotropy is a material property that describes how a substance can "thicken" over time.  Simple examples of thixotropic materials available in the house are in the kitchen (ketchup), the bathroom (toothpaste), the art studio (paints), and the toy box (silly putty).  Each of these materials if left untouched will become stiffer, but when the material is worked (or used) it will move more easily.  This concept also is used to describe the behavior of some naturally occurring clay soils.  Scientists and engineers have long observed this phenomenon in clays, but only a theorized or hypothesized explanation has been presented to date to explain the underlying mechanisms.  The work in this research project aims to examine and simulate the clay particle-scale development of thixotropy under various environmental conditions (time, water chemistry, and temperature) and at different size scales.  This innovative multiscale approach to understanding the mechanisms of thixotropy serves to advance the NSF mission of promoting the progress of science by filling a void of information utilizing recent advances in theory, experimentation, and computing.  The new knowledge gained in this work will aid in the design and construction of engineering systems involving soft clays, such as deep pile foundations, offshore pipelines, wind farm foundations, disposal of dredged materials, drilling mud stability, and seabed clay acoustic properties, among others.  The project also includes a significant outreach program to help attract under-represented minority students to STEM disciplines through publications and K-12 school activities and demonstrations.

Thixotropy is a fundamental soil behavior mechanism that governs multiple time-dependent engineering properties of soft clays (e.g., the evolution of stiffness, strength, and sensitivity over time).  While significant understanding of thixotropy of colloid systems has been achieved since the initiation of the field of thixotropy in the early 1920s, current knowledge on soil thixotropy is still based primarily on some pioneering work performed in and prior to the 1960s and, since then, new developments have been scarce and fragmental.  Such a paucity of new findings and the disparity in thixotropy research and advancement between colloid science and soil mechanics provide an impetus to this research.  Therefore, this collaborative project that integrates multiscale experimental and computational efforts is to study soft clay thixotropy.  The overall goal of the project is to create the enabling knowledge on the macroscale mechanical and microscale structural mechanisms of soft clay thixotropy and hence to append some new time-dependent soil behavior to the geotechnical knowledge base.  To achieve this goal, a congruent and comprehensive research program consisting of three primary thrusts is designed with synergistic collaboration among the three investigators from UMass Amherst and Drexel University with complementary expertise in macroscale mechanical testing, microscale fabric imaging, quantitative characterization of particle orientations, and coarse-grained molecular dynamics simulations.  The intellectual merit of the project stems from three aspects: (1) the geotechnical knowledge base on soil thixotropy will be expanded with new understanding, particularly the effects of physico-chemical factors such as temperature and porewater chemistry; (2) both the macroscale mechanical and microscale structural mechanisms of thixotropic hardening of soft clays will be uncovered via multiscale experimental and computational research; and (3) the linkage between quantitative time-dependent clay fabric evolution and macroscale thixotropic processes will be developed.  Because soil thixotropy plays an important role in many engineering problems, the project also can generate significant practical impacts to geotechnical engineering, particularly the design and construction of engineering systems involving soft clays.  Examples include evaluation of pile and suction caisson setup, design of wind farm foundations, and disposal of dredged materials, among others.  Moreover, the multiscale investigation methodology developed through this project can be generalized to other more complex soil research topics and can also serve as a generic approach for other basic research queries.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this collaborative project were to create the enabling knowledge and understanding on soft clay thixotropy, including both the macroscopic phenomenological behavior (e.g., the temporal development of undrained shear strength and stiffness) and microscopic mechanisms responsible for the time-dependent hardening and stiffening process. Thixotropy is one of the fundamental soil behavior mechanisms governing a range of time-dependent engineering properties of soft clays widely encountered in engineering practice. In fact, this special behavior has been or is being considered in certain designs by state and federal departments of transportation (DOTs) and offshore industry, such as driven piles and suction caissons for foundations of bridges and anchoring of floating offshore wind turbines. In this report, the project outcomes are summarized in two separate aspects: intellectual merits and broader impacts.

 

Project outcomes related to intellectual merits:

The experimental work conducted by the University of Massachusetts (UMass) Amherst Team consisted of both conventional, macroscopic mechanical testing to measure the temporal development of undrained shear strength and small strain shear modulus of 5 different soft clays for a maximum hardening time of up to 850 days and advanced microscopic characterization of time-dependent evolution of clay microstructure (e.g., clay particle orientation index (OI) and texture index (TI)) using both one-dimensional X-ray diffraction (1DXRD) and 2DXRD. Test variables included clay mineralogy, pore water salinity, and temperature. The comprehensive datasets covering a wide variety of physical and chemical factors can be used by others for the development of constitutive models incorporating thixotropy and/or other time-dependent behavior of soft clays.

 

Innovative and advanced analytical techniques based on both 1DXRD and 2DXRD for quantitative assessment of temporal evolution of clay microstructure using both OI and TI have been developed. The unique advancement was the applicability of these techniques to wet soft clays (but not dried soils or rocks). The developed micro-characterization techniques can be easily extended to study other fundamental soil behavior and properties and their underlying microscopic mechanisms, such as thixotropy of soft clays and anisotropy of hard rocks, shear band formation, and even progressive failure mechanisms.

 

Results of long-term macroscopic mechanical testing positively point out that the long-term thixotropic hardening and stiffening process can be divided into two drastically different stages: an initial, fast evolving stage at a relatively short period of time characterized by rapid increase in strength and stiffness, and a slowly-evolving stage for prolonged time featuring slow and moderate increase in strength and stiffness, some of which approach asymptotically to a constant ultimate value. 

 

For the studied five soft clays prepared at approximately their respective liquid limits, the maximum gains in undrained shear strength and shear modulus over a prolonged duration can be up to five times (e.g., for the Boston Blue Clay) of the remolded shear strength and 15 times of the remolded shear modulus (e.g., form the Onsøy clay). Therefore, designs incorporating the effects of clay thixotropy can be more cost-effective under the appropriate consideration of time and factor of safety.

 

Multiple mechanisms of soft clay thixotropy have been unraveled by microscale characterization, including (1) soil fabric evolution such as clay particle reorientation, aggregation, flocculation, (2) homogenization of prior disturbance, defects/flaws, microstructure (e.g., porosity distribution), and pore pressure, and (3) contact aging. Although these mechanisms may occur simultaneously during the duration of thixotropic hardening, the two dissimilar stages are controlled by different primary mechanisms. While the 1st stage may be affected by all of the above mechanisms, fabric evolution may play the primary role. However, in the 2nd stage, contact aging may become dominant upon the completion of fabric evolution occurring primarily in the 1st stage.

 

Other physical and chemical factors, such as water content, temperature, and porewater salinity, can also significantly affect the magnitude and rate of thixotropic hardening, and their influences can be further intervened by the primary factor: soil composition or clay mineralogy. 

 

Project outcomes related to broader impacts:

The project successfully attracted, trained, and mentored students of diverse origins and backgrounds in basic and advanced geotechnical laboratory testing including 2 undergraduate, 1 high school, and 4 graduate students. One woman student (M. Harris) started training as an undergraduate and then continued to the graduate program at UMass Amherst. Of these 7 students, 6 are women students. One woman student was a graduate from Smith College, a top-ranked liberal arts private college. 

 

Research results and findings have been and will be continuously disseminated via journal publications and conference proceedings so that the impact can reach out to different communities and disciplines worldwide. To date, one conference paper has been published, three journal papers have been submitted for review, and two more journal manuscripts are under preparation. In addition, results have also been disseminated in some local conference presentations and webinars for wider audience, including international students and researchers.
